title: "Tree mark | Plot"
---

# Tree mark [^0.4.3](https://github.com/observablehq/plot/releases/tag/v0.4.3 "added in v0.4.3") [​](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree\#tree-mark)

The **tree mark** produces tree diagrams using the [tree transform](https://observablehq.com/plot/transforms/tree). It is a [composite mark](https://observablehq.com/plot/features/marks#marks), consisting of a [link](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/link) to render links from parent to child, an optional [dot](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/dot) for nodes, and one or two [text](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/text) for node labels. The link mark uses the [treeLink transform](https://observablehq.com/plot/transforms/tree#treeLink), while the dot and text marks use the [treeNode transform](https://observablehq.com/plot/transforms/tree#treeNode).

For example, here is a little family tree of Greek gods.

/Chaos/Chaos/Eros/Chaos/Erebus/Chaos/Tartarus/Chaos/Gaia/Chaos/Gaia/Mountains/Chaos/Gaia/Pontus/Chaos/Gaia/UranusEros/Chaos/ErosErebus/Chaos/ErebusTartarus/Chaos/TartarusMountains/Chaos/Gaia/MountainsPontus/Chaos/Gaia/PontusUranus/Chaos/Gaia/UranusChaos/ChaosGaia/Chaos/Gaia [Fork](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot-tree-and-link "Open on Observable")

js

```
Plot.plot({
  axis: null,
  height: 100,
  margin: 10,
  marginLeft: 40,
  marginRight: 120,
  marks: [\
    Plot.tree(gods, {textStroke: "white"})\
  ]
})
```

Here `gods` is an array of slash-separated paths, similar to paths in a file system. Each path represents the hierarchical position of a node in the tree.

js

```
gods = [\
  "Chaos/Gaia/Mountains",\
  "Chaos/Gaia/Pontus",\
  "Chaos/Gaia/Uranus",\
  "Chaos/Eros",\
  "Chaos/Erebus",\
  "Chaos/Tartarus"\
]
```

As a more complete example, here is a visualization of a software package hierarchy.

\_\_/flare/query/methods/\_ [Fork](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot-tree-flare "Open on Observable")

js

```
Plot.plot({
  axis: null,
  margin: 10,
  marginLeft: 30,
  marginRight: 160,
  width: 688,
  height: 1800,
  marks: [\
    Plot.tree(flare, {path: "name", delimiter: ".", textStroke: "white"})\
  ]
})
```

The **treeLayout** option specifies the layout algorithm. The tree mark uses the Reingold–Tilford “tidy” tree algorithm, [d3.tree](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/tree), by default. The [cluster](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree#cluster) convenience method sets **treeLayout** to [d3.cluster](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/cluster), aligning the leaf nodes.

\_\_/flare/query/methods/\_ [Fork](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot-cluster-flare "Open on Observable")

js

```
Plot.plot({
  axis: null,
  margin: 10,
  marginLeft: 30,
  marginRight: 160,
  width: 688,
  height: 2400,
  marks: [\
    Plot.cluster(flare, {path: "name", treeSort: "node:height", delimiter: ".", textStroke: "white"})\
  ]
})
```

Here is an example of a custom **treeLayout** implementation, assigning _node_.x and _node_.y.

js

```
function indent() {
  return (root) => {
    root.eachBefore((node, i) => {
      node.y = node.depth;
      node.x = i;
    });
  };
}
```

This produces an indented tree layout.

\_\_/flare/query/methods/\_ [Fork](https://observablehq.com/@observablehq/plot-custom-tree-layout "Open on Observable")

js

```
Plot.plot({
  axis: null,
  inset: 10,
  insetRight: 120,
  round: true,
  width: 200,
  height: 3600,
  marks: Plot.tree(flare, {
    path: "name",
    delimiter: ".",
    treeLayout: indent,
    strokeWidth: 1,
    curve: "step-before",
    textStroke: "none"
  })
})
```

The tree mark currently does not inform the default layout; you may find it necessary to set the **height** and **margin** [layout options](https://observablehq.com/plot/features/plots#layout-options) for readability.

## Tree options [​](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree\#tree-options)

The following options are supported:

- **fill** \- the dot and text fill color; defaults to _node:internal_
- **stroke** \- the link stroke color; inherits **fill** by default
- **strokeWidth** \- the link stroke width
- **strokeOpacity** \- the link stroke opacity
- **strokeLinejoin** \- the link stroke linejoin
- **strokeLinecap** \- the link stroke linecap
- **strokeMiterlimit** \- the link stroke miter limit
- **strokeDasharray** \- the link stroke dash array
- **strokeDashoffset** \- the link stroke dash offset
- **marker** \- the link start and end marker
- **markerStart** \- the link start marker
- **markerEnd** \- the link end marker
- **dot** \- if true, whether to render a dot; defaults to false if no link marker
- **title** \- the text and dot title; defaults to _node:path_
- **text** \- the text label; defaults to _node:name_
- **textStroke** \- the text stroke; defaults to _white_
- **textLayout** \- the text anchoring layout
- **dx** \- the text horizontal offset; defaults to 6
- **dy** \- the text vertical offset; defaults to 0

Any additional _options_ are passed through to the constituent link, dot, and text marks and their corresponding treeLink or treeNode transform.

The **textLayout** option [^0.6.9](https://github.com/observablehq/plot/releases/tag/v0.6.9 "added in v0.6.9") controls how text labels are anchored to the node. Two layouts are supported:

- _mirrored_ \- leaf-node labels are left-anchored, and non-leaf nodes right-anchored
- _normal_ \- all labels are left-anchored

If the **treeLayout** is d3.tree or d3.cluster, the **textLayout** defaults to _mirrored_; otherwise it defaults to _normal_.

## tree( _data_, _options_) [​](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree\#tree)

js

```
Plot.tree(flare, {path: "name", delimiter: "."})
```

Returns a new tree mark with the given _data_ and _options_.

## cluster( _data_, _options_) [​](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree\#cluster)

js

```
Plot.cluster(flare, {path: "name", delimiter: "."})
```

Like [tree](https://observablehq.com/plot/marks/tree#tree), except sets the **treeLayout** option to [d3.cluster](https://d3js.org/d3-hierarchy/cluster), aligning leaf nodes, and defaults the **textLayout** option to _mirrored_.
